titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. I went to Boston this morning with my father; Louisa Smith, and Mr: W. Smith’s two sons Isaac and Thomas, who have spent the week at my father’s. I went into the House of Representatives, and heard a debate of about an hour, and was present at the taking of the yeas and nays— Pass’d the rest of the morning on trifles of business. Dined at Dr: Warren’s, in company with the Trustees of the Agricultural Society— Governor Strong was there— We returned to Quincy early in the afternoon— My brother and W. Shaw came home with us— I was quite unwell, the whole day.— Read part of Juvenal’s 10th: Satire.

2. Heard Mr: Cushman— In the afternoon I went down to my father’s— And all my family was there— Came home early in the Evening— Th: B. Johnson arrived in Boston last Evening from Charleston. Reading.— I finished the 10th: and began the 11th: Satire of Juvenal.— Read also Johnson’s Vanity of Human Wishes— I think it not
equal to the original— The examples of Wolsey, Charles 12. Laud, and the Emperor,are by no means so striking to the purpose of the poem as Sejanus, Annibal, Demosthenes, Cicero, and Xerxes. The miseries of Old Age, are painted with much more energy by Juvenal than by Johnson, and his illustrations are all from well known Stories; instead of such names as Lydiat, and Vane, and Sedley, whose stories one must hunt up before we know how to sympathize with them— I also read a Sermon of Tillotson, the 70th.
3. I dined at my father’s— In the Evening, we had company at our own house— My brother came up from Boston.— Continued reading the 11th: Satire of Juvenal.— Read also a few pages of Rabelais.

4. Mrs: Adams went in to Boston this morning with my brother, and returned this evening with her brother Thomas— I went with Captain Beale this afternoon to Neponsit Bridge, where there was a meeting of the Directors. After transacting the business I returned with Mr: Beale to my father’s; and thence walk’d home with George— Reading— Finish’d the 11th: and began the 12th: Satire of Juvenal. Read also two or three of Martyn’s letters on Botany.

5. Captain Beale called this forenoon and invited me to go with him on a fishing party to-morrow— Agreed. In the afternoon we all went down to my fathers— Walk’d home in the Evening— Reading—finished the 12th: Satire of Juvenal— Read also two or three of the Botanical Letters with the Ladies, and examined some flowers.

6. I went down to Captain Beale’s this Morning, but the weather being bad, and the wind contrary, he had concluded not to go upon the party this day— I spent the morning chiefly at my father’s, in transplanting young nectarine, and peach-trees. Went home to dinner— Read the 9th: letter of Martin’s Botany, to the Ladies and examined a few flowers.— Read also a few pages of the Modern philosopher’s, a novel by Miss Hamilton.

7. The weather continued such as to prevent our fishing party, which now must be indefinitely postponed. Pass’d the whole day at home— Read Juvenal Satire 13. which I formerly translated— Read also to the Ladies, a couple of Martyn’s letters on Botany; and examined several flowers— My Mother, & Sister Adams were here this afternoon, and brought home George— Read in the Evening the Modern Philosophers.

8. Mr: T. Johnson and Eliza went to Boston this morning, and Eliza returned at Night with my brother— The rest of the family, except George, whom we left at home, dined at my father’s. I set out a number of Peach-trees— Read Juvenal Satire 13. Martyn on Botany— And the Modern Philosophers.

9. A Cold North-East Storm, with continual rain the whole day, detained us all at home— In the Evening I opened a couple of my boxes of books— Read two Sermons of Tillotson, Vol: 4— 71. 72. And finished the 13th: Satire of Juvenal.

10. I went into Boston this Morning with my brother; received part of my Rent from Mr: Delille. Saw General Jackson, respecting, the note of Mr: Swan endorsed by him; belonging to the Assignees of Robert Bird— He supposes Mr: Swan to have paid it. Called at the Bank U.S.— Received of Mrs: Mackey the dividends due on a Share in West-Boston Bridge— I agreed to purchase two shares more of Dr: Spooner— Saw Mr: Dexter, and had a long conversation with him, respecting Mrs:
Mrs: Hall’s Affairs; we finally concluded that the only remedy, if any remains is a Bill in Chancery, and I took the papers with me to draw one.— Dined at Whitcomb’s— Called at Mr: Gardner’s Office, and looked at the record of Swan’s protested Bill.— Met the Commissioners of Bankruptcy, in the case of Patrick Phillips, on a 3d: dividend, and sat untill 7. in the Evening; to meet again the 12th:— My brother returned with me to Quincy this Evening.

11. Had a very bad night with George, who is unwell. I was employed all the morning in writing to the Assignees of Robert Bird, and in drawing a Bill in Chancery for Mrs: Hall, which I find it will be impossible to have ready for this term of the Circuit Court— Part of the afternoon engaged on the same business— We went down to my fathers to tea—returned early, Mrs: Adams being unwell.— I called at Mr: Cranch’s; and passed an hour with him— Mrs: Quincy and Miss Morton were here this forenoon.

12. Mrs: Adams and Eliza Johnson went into Boston together, and I took in my brother’s Chaise— Met the Commissioners of Patrick Phillips, and adjourned to Monday the 24th: at 3. P.M.— Transacted various other business, and dined at Mr: W. Payne’s, with a small company of Ladies and Gentlemen— We returned to Quincy late in the Evening.

13. My Mother was here this morning— In the afternoon I went with all my family to Mr: Quincy’s.— He has just moved out from Boston for the Summer. Coming home, my brother pass’d us, on his return from Boston— Read Juvenal Satire 14. which I translated, but not well— And Martyn on Botany.

14. Summer weather is approaching. This day was so warm that I could not go out in the first part of the day. We went to an Evening party at Mr: Dexter’s in Roxbury, where was a Company of about 50 persons, mostly Ladies— It was Midnight before we came home— Read over again Gifford’s Juvenal— Satire 14.— And also a Botanical Letter of Martyn— I am studying the Table of Linnaeus’s Orders.

15. Mr: Kirkland was here this Afternoon— We all went to my father’s to tea— Mr: & Mrs: Otis, the elder were there— We met them going to our house— Mr: Watson his daughter and two nieces also came in to tea. George was unwell, and Mrs: A went home early.— Mr: & Mrs: Dexter, and their daughters came afterwards. I came home late in the Evening— Read some letters in Martyn’s Botany— Studied the Table.

16. Heard Mr: Whitney of Hingham— Dined at my father’s. difficulty in bringing George home. Read two Sermons of Tillotson—the 73d: and 74th:— Walk on the farm in the Evening, with Mrs: Adams and Eliza. Weather at high Summer heat.

17. Continuation of the warm weather. Put George to School to Mrs: Bracket— In the afternoon I took him with me down to my fathers— Evening party at Mr: T. Greenleaf’s— I came home very late. Read part of Juvenal Satire 15.— Mrs: Adams very unwell this morning.

18. I found this morning, eight of the peach Stones, which I planted at the beginning of May, shooting sprouts from the ground. This therefore settled a point about which I was doubtful— My Mother and Sister Adams were here at tea this afternoon. After which I went home with my mother. Walk’d back— Finished the 15th: Satire of Juvenal— Read Martyn’s letters 11. and 12— Also Drummond’s translation of Perseus—at. 2–6. and part of his notes.

19. Heat still continues, and confined me, great part of the day to the house— In the afternoon however, I took George, down from School with me to my father’s— I find two of the nuts I sowed last Autumn, are coming up— Rode home— Read the 16th: and last Satire of Juvenal— Generally considered spurious; and therefore not translated by Gifford.— Martyn, letter 13.— Tableau de Paris Vol. 1.

20. Eliza Johnson went to Boston this morning with Mr: T. Greenleaf, and return’d at Night.— I bathed at 5 in the morning; at the landing place, which I so much frequented in my childhood; for the same purpose. The morning, and last Night were of excessive heat; but an East Wind made the day more than cool.— Read the Prologue to Persius’s Satires; and Drummond’s Translation.— Martyn, letters 14. 15.— Tableau de Paris. Vol. 1.

21. Dined at my father’s, with the family— My brother was gone to Boston; but returned before we came home. I transplanted some peach-trees from the stone, and one cherry-tree— One of the cherry-stones I sowed this Spring behind my Barn has also thrown up a shoot— Read Martyn, Letter 16. in part— And Persius Sat: 1. with Drummond’s Translation; or rather Paraphrase— The original is indeed so obscure, that any other mode of translation would be unintelligible.

22. Dined at Mr: T. Greenleaf’s with the Club, whom I invited for next Saturday to my house. Afternoon with my father— Came home with Mrs: Cranch.— Read part of Persius, Satire 1. and the conclusion of Martyn’s letter 16. I examined a number of flowers; but the further I advance in botanical Studies the more I find to do; and the more doubtful I am whether the use will pay the cost.

23. Heard Mr: Flint at Meeting, this Morning; and Mr: Gardner at Church this afternoon. W. Shaw dined with us— Mrs: Adams and Eliza after Church took a ride to Milton.— I pass’d the afternoon, and most of the Evening at my father’s— Read Tillotson’s Sermons 75— On the Nature and Office of Good Angels and 76. on the sufferings of Good Men.

24. Went to Boston this Morning, with Mrs: Adams; and returned home late in the Evening.— Suffered much from the warmth of the weather— In the morning I had little business to do;—and left that little undone. Called on Mr: Jos: Russell; but he was not in town.— Dined at Whitcomb’s Ordinary. At 4 in the afternoon I met the Commissioners of Patrick Phillips, and we finished his business.— On our way home we called at Mr: S. A. Otis’s, and pass’d an hour there.— His brother Joseph was with him.— Read Nothing this day.

25— The excessive heat of the weather confined me to my house and Garden the whole day. I read a few lines in Persius Satire 1.— Tableau de Paris Vol 1. and 2.— La Paysanne Pervertie, and Martyn Letter 17. Mrs: Adams unwell.— Our Thermometer at 86.

26. Mr: Quincy called on me this morning, and informed me that the Corporation of Harvard University, had the day before yesterday elected me Professor of Oratory, on the Boylston foundation— The subject has been mentioned to me, several times in the course of the last three years— But I yet know not whether it will be proper or expedient for me to accept this situation— Spent the afternoon and Evening at my father’s— Mr: Quincy and his family were there. Mrs: Adams was so unwell, she could not go. We observed an Eclipse of the Sun, just before Night.— Read a few lines of Persius—and La Paysanne Pervertie— Wrote to Mrs: S. Hall of Barbadoes.

27. My father and Mother called here this forenoon.— Afternoon and part of the Evening at Mr: Cranch’s— Mr: Quincy and his family were there.— And Mrs: Bond.— Wrote to Mrs: Hall— Read Martyn Letter 18. and La Paysanne Pervertie.

28. I went into Boston with Mr: Quincy, late this morning— We dined together at Whitcomb’s— There was only Mr: T. Johnson there beside— At 5 in the afternoon, with Mr: Quincy I attended the meeting of the Society for the study of
natural History; who are now engaged upon Botany— Judge Davis was the lecturer— At 7 the meeting terminated, and we returned immediately to Quincy.

29. Went to my father’s this morning, and soon returned with my Mother— The Saturday’s Club dined with me; my father was in Boston, to attend a meeting of the Trustees of the Agricultural Society. My Mother, Sister Adams, and Louisa Smith dined with us. It was late before the company broke up— Walk in the Evening— Read nothing this day.

30. Heard Mr: Whitney— Dined at my father’s— Eliza Johnson with George dined at Mr: Black’s— This afternoon Dr: and Mrs: Howard, and Mr: & Mrs: W. Sullivan came out from Boston to see us; but Mrs: Adams being at my father’s, they immediately went there— Mr: & Mrs: Daniel Greenleaf were here in the Evening— Read Tillotson’s Sermons 77 and 78— Finished la Paysanne Pervertie, a very miserable novel.

Day. Rise usually between 5 and 6.— Read or Ramble in my Gardens untill 9. Breakfast— Pass the time between that and dinner miscellaneously, reading writing, or gathering flowers in the fields. dine at one— In the afternoon Often go to my father’s, where I pass the time nearly as at home, untill Evening. This now scarcely comes untill 9 at Night— About 10 our day closes— This is a register of idleness which I cannot excuse to myself— The state of my health, and the prescriptions of my physicians and friends is all I can plead for it; but as I am much recovered I hope it will not last through the next month.
